title.narrative: FAO HUM 2017-2020
FAO HUM 2017-2020

description.narrative: The three main drivers of food crises in 2020 were conflict and insecurity, economic shocks due to the compounding effects of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), and weather extremes. Households that depend on farming and pastoralism for their livelihoods continue to be among the worst affected, with their livelihoods, food security and nutrition at serious risk. To protect and restore peoples agricultural livelihoods and increase their resilience to threats and crises, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) works to improve preparedness, implement effective response and promote sustainable recovery. In order to achieve this, FAO is among the organizations leading global efforts in anticipatory action, an approach that translates early warnings into activities that reduce the impact of disasters. By investing in agricultural production critical to enhancing food security, nutrition and income generation FAOs support before and during emergencies saves livelihoods and builds resilience.

Detta beslut avser en större ändring av insats mellan Sida och FAO för att möjliggöra humanitärt stöd i tre kriser under 2020 (Afghanistan, Nigeria och Somalia). Stödet omfattar också oallokerad finansiering till FAO:s särskilda fond för katastrofer och rehabilitering, SFERA, som är ytterligare en mekanism för att tillgängliggöra stöd till FAO i händelser av akuta kriser. Sida kommer under 2020 att fortsatt engagera sig i att stärka det humanitära systemet genom att finansiering till det globala matsäkerhetsklustret (gFSC). FAO:s kontor för utvärdering (OED) kommer under 2020 att genomföra en utvärdering av de fem Sida-finansierade projekten i Sahel (Tchad, Kamerun, Mali och Niger).
Beslutet omfattar finansiellt stöd till FAO om 67 683 193 SEK.

This is a “Major Amendment of Contribution” between Sida and FAO to allow for humanitarian response in three crises (Afghanistan, Nigeria and Somalia) for 2020. This Amendment also includes support for unallocated funding to FAO's Special Fund for Emergency and Rehabilitation (SFERA), capacity-building support to the global Food Security Cluster (gFSC) and funding for evaluation in regard to FAO Sida multi-year resilience projects in the Sahel. This Decision concerns a financial contribution to FAO amounting to 67,683,193 Swedish kronor (SEK).

description.narrative: During 2020, Sida funded 11 humanitarian projects totalling 97,7 million SEK. Sida funding enabled FAO to directly support nearly 454 000 people, as well as millions of people indirectly, that had affected by conflict and political instability, economic shocks due to COVID-19 and climate-related disasters, such as droughts and floods. The main challenge for FAO in 2020 was related to the COVID-19 pandemic which made access to project sites more challenging. The use of funds through the Special Fund for Emergency and Rehabilitation Activities (SFERA) was critical in order to respond to multiple crises in a timely manner. In 2020, the contribution of Sida to SFERA funded for example COVID-19 and drought response projects in Kenya, anticipatory action in Mongolia and the fight against Desert Locust in Ethiopia and Somalia. In Ethiopia and Somalia, the focus was on reducing the negative consequences of the desert locust outbreak, which was the worst in 25 years, by strengthening food security among farmers and pastoralists. The support reached 11,000 households in Ethiopia and 14,000 households in Somalia, prioritising households with women, the elderly and children affected by malnutrition.
